Message.Msg: I think market correction is a normal cycle of the stock market. Yes I agree a change of Fed policy could trigger a market correction. But this time around it is really very different because the uptrend movements is really very gradual while reaching record level in the s/p particularly so the market is absorbing this record level in gradual manner likewise. So I do not foresee market correction in the short-term unless until we experience an upside movements aggressively. If we have a market correction, I think YHOO can withhold his ground.

Topic.Title: If analysts were as smart as they think they are they would be running Yahoo.

Message.Msg: I think the variables pointing YHOO uptrend movement intact. I agree YHOO will be in the $30’s this year. An upgrade PT of $30 seems to be the norm PT mostly given by noted specialty analysts. Likewise none of these well-known analysts disagree with YHOO acquiring Tumblr, meaning a good deal for YHOO. Another important variable that is forthcoming is the Alibaba IPO. I think this is really huge to YHOO. In my opinion the IPO valuation would tell us how much we have to tack in to YHOO share.

Message.Msg: We also fundamentally believe that our pattern portfolio is undervalued so we think the value of our IP will be realized as we make progress and protecting our life under our patterns. We have a dozen patterns, three of which are in the emerging pay-per-call space, a multibillion ad revenue opportunity in mobile. We’re actively reviewing potential infringes of our pay-per-call intellectual property and expect to take action to preserve our IP raised in mobile later this year." Source: Transcript of Conference Call Local Corp (Read the complete text on Seeking Alpha) Less •12 patents issued from Local Corp, 8 pending »Key patents –Local web indexing (for indexing local web sites across the web) –Pay per call for local and commercial searches via a mobile device (multiple patents) •The billion dollar industry question: How do we monetize mobile? –Dynamic cascading menu search (for product search on tablets and smart phones) –Bulk domain registration and content management (for very large scale SEO

Message.Title: yahoo beating amazon
Message.Msg: Yahoo! has a stronger strategy than Amazon Yahoo! (NASDAQ: YHOO) is in talks to buy out Hulu. I estimated that acquiring Hulu would cost in excess of $2 billion. Marissa Mayer's strategy in movie streaming by buying out Hulu is stronger than Amazon, because Hulu already has a large content library (not as big as Amazon or Netflix), but at least it has one. It also has a user base of approximately 4 million subscribers, giving Yahoo! an effective base to grow from, and if Yahoo! was to expand Hulu’s services in key international markets, it can actually carve out a niche for itself while co-existing with Netflix. Something Amazon may not be able to do because Amazon’s intent is to compete directly with Netflix, whereas Hulu focuses more on TV shows and a narrower target market. If Yahoo! buys out Hulu, it is unlikely that Yahoo! would risk changing Hulu’s brand name into Yahoo! Hulu, or pull a brand-extension stunt that could hurt the company’s performance. Imagine if every Procter & Gamble product had the name Procter & Gamble in it, would you honestly be able to distinguish the difference between Olay, Vicks, Tide, and Listerine if the brand name Procter & Gamble was in each of these different products? Having separate brand names help consumers to differentiate products and services, which is why Hulu could be the best investment decision Yahoo! could make in light of its current financial position.
buy them now anyway. Don't be greedy and miss out.

YHOO has huge money coming from Alibaba IPO but they have the cash now to do the deal. YHOO got over $3B+ cash right now. read Eric Jackson's article from 5.23

Then let us go for Hulu. I think MM really like it very much to acquire Hulu. There is no doubt she has a plan why she wants to acquire it. YHOO has the money--do it MM as long as it fits your plan.

Well this feels like deja vu - first -round bids are due this week. Though they do seem more intent on selling this time. Guggenheim (Levinsohn) will also be making a bid. So I guess Yahoo! does not have an edge through Mickie Rosen. Although if Guggenheim is the victor - well - let's just say I am surprised Ms. Rosen is still @ Yahoo! - just an observation. I do recall Chernin's bid a months back was $500 million, but everyone seems interested once again - they are valued @ closer to 2.5 billion. Tried to link to story from LA Times - but it's not white-listed - so won't accept the link. The Verge has a story this evening as well - based on Times article. Would be nice if the mods worked on expanding that white-list - just sayin'.
Got your back. Thumbs up for both of you :)
Glad somebody reads
I see we still agree hulu is the way to go. I think Yahoo has the edge. With their current momentum it will get any companies attention when MM knocks on their door. They are serious.

I really like what MM is doing acquiring those small companies and integrate them to YHOO; hopefully unique but becoming niche specialty and of course engineering talents joining YHOO. Sooner this will eventually pay off to YHOO.

Would have loved them to grab hulu last time around, for much less than they will need to pay now. Yes, they do want it but they are up against some stiff competition. I was thinking they had an edge with Rosen, but I don't know how badly Levinsohn wants it? Guggenheim Partners are advising Hulu right?
Yes, that's my understanding. I think the current momentum of Yahoo has a huge value to anyone selling their company. Yahoo is a company on the move with lots of open road in front of them

Message.Title: What I found out during a simple dinner about Tumblr......
Message.Msg: Long story short I met a good friend for dinner this week. Besides the obvious things friends talk about we got around to what investments/stock picks we have. I brought up Yahoo and Tumbler. He remarked.....oh yes Tumblr - all my kids use it! As a matter of fact their entire H.S. uses it. When I heard this I was totally flabbergasted. I asked if his kids still us FB and he said "occasionally." Again I was shocked. When I inquired further he said that they don't think it's worth their time anymore. It's no longer a favorite with kids their age. Sooooo.....while this example is not a scientific finding, I have to go with gut feeling. I"m not worried about monetization yet. Let's give MM a chance to marinate this big bird. For those who say Yahoo made past mistakes with purchases I wholeheartedly agree. They made lots of foolish large buys in the past. However, it's apples and oranges folks. The past CEO's did NOT come from Google. They were not "trained" at Google. It has always been a patchwork team with bad genes from non-inspiring companies. I say we will soon see the Google DNA take Yahoo to higher heights. Give it a chance, these guys are not dumb dumbs like the past teams. Also, stop listening to the "experts" - notice that it's 50/50 of for and against the acquisition. That tells me they know nothing. I rather trust what the H.S. kids are doing NOW vs. what the adult "experts" think Yahoo should have done or did do. Again.......I could be 100% wrong......but what if..........? LOL Good luck to all longs!
